description:
Sun: The center star of the Solar System.

Active, central, embracing energy; Masculine Principle.

Moon: Celestial body that orbits the Earth.

Passive energy; Feminine principle

Mercury: 1) First planet from the Sun.
Swiftness; intellect; alchemy.

2) The Fluid intellectual conduit that is the passive principle in Alchemy, bridging Sulphur to Salt.

Venus: Second planet from the Sun.

Beauty; Goodness; All-encompassing rejoicing

Earth: Third planet from the Sun and home of mankind.

Yin; Salt (alc); Receptive to Heaven

Mars: 1) Fourth planet from the Sun.

Strength; Warfare

2) Roman deity of war

Jupiter: 1) Fifth planet from the Sun.

Thunder; lightning; Judgment; Kingship.

2) Roman deity Zeus equivalent

Saturn: Sixth planet from the Sun.

Time; Darkness; Providence; Fate

Uranus: Seventh planet from the Sun.

Knows implicitly the harmony of the solar system, then resolves phrases.

Emperor; Willful; Surprising

Neptune: Eighth planet from the Sun.

Storms; Persecution; Serenity; Imagination

Pluto: Was the Ninth planet from the Sun; no longer considered a planet in astronomy.

Brings something new from without

Aries: First sign of the Zodiac.

Fiery coming-forth in rulership.

Taurus: Second sign of the Zodiac.

Earthen steady work

Gemini: Third sign of the Zodiac.

Joining in providence

Cancer: Fourth sign of the Zodiac.

Providing renewal

Leo: Fifth sign of the Zodiac.

Exploding ferocity

Virgo: Sixth sign of the Zodiac.

Pure beholder

Libra: Seventh sign of the Zodiac.

Freedom and balance

Scorpio: Eighth sign of the Zodiac.

Force of life and death

Sagittarius: Ninth sign of the Zodiac.

Directive pointing

Capricorn: Tenth sign of the Zodiac.

Timed forcefulness

Aquarius: Eleventh sign of the Zodiac.

A going-forward

Pisces: Twelfth sign of the Zodiac.

Rejoicing in completion

Strength of activity with respect to time.

Each element has one of each
(4 elements x 3 cardinalities = 12 signs)

Cardinal: Initiating explosion.
Mutable: Oscillating sustenance. Fixed: Sustained energy.
Initiating explosion of an element.
Oscillating sustenance of an element.
Sustained energy of an element

Alchemical division of the world.

Perhaps consider as a "vertical" division, rather than as compteing with the periodic table of elements.

4 Elements: Fire üúÇ, Water üúÑ, Air üúÅ, Earth üúÉ
+ üúÄ Spirit

Spirit: In some sense non-elemental. Also known as Ether or Quintessence.

"Spirit rules the 4 elements and is the close kin of fire."

Fire: First element, positive and masculine (greater yang). The highest plane.

Emanates and initiates toward a goal.

Water: Second element and most feminine (greater yin). The second highest plane.

Creates and holds things together.

Air: Third element, positive and masculine (lesser yang). The second lowest plane.

Forms and orients things.

Earth: Fourth element, negative and feminine (lesser yin)

Action of things.

The tetragrammaton, or Name of God according to Judaism.

Each letter represents a World (Plane) or Element.
Aristotle's theory of Four Causes, according to which the activity of the world can be divided into Final Cause, Material Cause, Formal Cause, and Efficient Cause acting upon Prime Matter.
The fundamental material that is acted upon in the world, as understood without causal properties.

The Aim or Teleology (telos) of a substance.

For example, the final cause of an eye is seeing.

The material composition of a substance.

For example, the eye has rodes and cones, etc.

The Idea or Form operative in a substance.

For example, the eye is spherical, with a hole for the optic nerve.

The mechanical activity of a substance, as in billiard-balls hitting one another.

For example, the eye makes saccades, quick unconscious movements.
The Original World of Man
The Highest Plane of God's manifestation, of Emanation.
The Second Highest Plane of God's manifestation, of Creation.
The Second Lowest Plane of God's manifestation, of Formation.
The Lowest and Most Immediate Plane of God's manifestation, of Action.

The 5 Tattvas of Indian Metaphysics, corresponding to the Five Elements. Each can also be paired with the other, for a total of 30.

They are acted on by the Three Gunnas, which correspond to the Tria Prima (Sulphur, Mercury Salt) of Alchemy, which also has 4 elements (+spirit).

You can meditate on Tattvas to improve inner vision.
Lesser Yang
Greater Yang
Lesser Yin
Greater Yin
Sulphur: The Oily, fiery, consuming active principle in Alchemy.
Salt: The Alkali Vehicle of Reaction in Alchemy.
Mercury: The Fluid intellectual conduit that is the passive principle in Alchemy, bridging Sulphur to Salt.

The three Gunas of Indian metaphysics, corresponding to the Tria Prima: Sattvas, Tamas, and Rajas.

The Gunas act upon the Tattvas or elements.
Upward alchemical activity of the Mind, the Fruit of Which is Wisdom.
Downard activity of the Body, the Fruit of which is Ignorance.
Midspace alchemical activity of the Soul, the Fruit of which is Lust.
The Chakras are energy-centers of the body, which can be meditated upon and in some sense "opened" (under proper guidance)
1: Crown - The Original Emanation of God as a unity, asa  point; of Pluto
2: Will - The Exertion of Intuition, of Mercy; also the Line; of Neptune
3: Understanding - The Providential Binding Sea, of Severity; also the Triangle; of Saturn, but also Mercury
4: Lordship - The Principle of Rulership, of Mercy; of Jupiter.
5: Strength  - The Principle of Warfare, of Severity; of Mars.
6: Love or Beauty - The Center, the Heart; the perpetual Sun.
7: Victory - Beauty of Victory, of Venus
8: Splendor - Sparkling Intellect and the Mercurial Principle
9: The Foundation - The Mysterious Psyche, the Foundation and Our Connection to Tipareth (Sun) from Malkuth (Earth).
10: The Kingdom - Earth, Glory, Immediacy, in which all is immanent.
The "hidden" Knowledge Sephiroth, connecting Chokmah and Binah.
The Veil that prevents our grasping things as they exist in simplicity within the 1-2-3 Upper Triad of the Tree of Life.
Tattva (Indian element) of Fire, Anger
Tattva (Indian element) of Air, Attachment
Tattva (Indian element) of Water, Lust
Tattva (Indian element) of Earth, Greed
Tattva (Indian element) of Spirit, Pride
Bindu, Upper-Back of Head - Chakra of Consciousness (alternative Chakra; not one of the 7; may correspond to Daath)
Muladhara, Root - 7th Chakra of Kundalini coiled at base of spine.
Svadhisthana, Sacral - 6th Chakra of Unconscious at genital region (corresonds to Yesod).
Manipura, Solar - 5th Chakra of Transformation at Solar Plexus or Above Navel.
Anahata, Heart - 4th Chakra of Balance at Heart (corresponds to Tiphareth)
Vishuddhi, Throat - 3rd Chakra of Purity at Throat (may correspond to Daath or the Veil).
Ajna, Third Eye - 2nd Chakra of Awakening at 3rd Eye (center of forehead above eye brows; corresponds to the Veil)
Sahasrara, Crown - 1st Chakra of Pure Liberation at "crown" above head (corresponds to Kether)
Jewish conception of God's manifestation as 10 disrete Sephiroth and 22 Hebrew Letters Under 4 Worlds or Elements, as adapted by Esotericists and formulated as the "Tree of Life"

The planets, including Earth, Sun, Moon, and Pluto, as understood by the Ancients and Alchemists.

One presumes that in the properties of the planets one finds arrayed the properties of man, if not God Himself

The 12 Astrological Signs, or Constellations which apparently envelop the Earth in a procession, as conceptualized by the Ancients and Alchemists.

One presumes that in the properties of the zodiac one finds arrayed the properties of man, if not God
Of a planet, in relation to a Sign of the Zodiac: The planet's primary force is strengthened
Of a planet, in relation to a Sign of the Zodiac: The planet's special qualities are illuminated
